In 1944, there was Smith v.

In 1950, there was Sweatt v.

Yes.
Throughout the South, Thurgood Marshall was known as public enemy number one.

And then there came the nomination in 1967.
Now, there's some history I had no idea about.
I understand President Lyndon Johnson wasn't exactly thrilled about nominating Marshall for the Supreme Court.
First of all, Marshall was going to be facing the very senators who represented the states in the South that Marshall had changed.

So how did LBJ's White House get the votes?
One of the great things about this saga is that it was really the sharp mastery of Lyndon Johnson to encourage 20 Southern senators not to vote.
He persuaded them to do that by saying, look, in 1965, I passed a voting rights act, and so more blacks in your Southern communities are going to be going to the polls.
I won't help you win next time if you harm me on this Marshall nomination.

What happened there in 1967?
